content.description: This pleasant route climbs the right side of the south-facing rib of the West Buttress that is detached and slightly west of the main Sawmill Wall. Consistent climbing past several bulges for nearly 100 feet finishes at a steel carabiner/mussy anchor. The route was named for an unbelievably ancient rappel anchor found in a slot to the right of the climbing about halfway up: a barely-wedged flake of rock about the size of a Popular Mechanics magazine that came off with the flick of a toe.
content.location: It is the obvious first route encountered on the south- facing rib.

content.description: Take the rib, corner, and face with increasing difficulty and use excellent underclings to clip to bolt above the roof. Move up and slightly right, then immediately cut left above the roof to an easier finish.
content.location: The main wall of the West Buttress has a roof about Â¾ of the way up. This route takes the line under the right side.

content.description: Pleasant and consistent climbing with a mild crux at the overlap climbs past a slight bulge, sloping ledge, and final headwall to chains.
content.location: This is the left of two routes that begin on a series of stepped ledges on the left side of the wall.

content.description: Varied climbing up patina and flakes, with rests, leads to a step left finishing up an easy corner.
content.location:
Start on the west-facing wall on the shelf above and left of the start of

Red Sling of Courage

.

content.description:
Pleasant and consistent climbing with a crux at bolt 3 leads past the bulge then up the final wall to chains. This is just a bit steeper and harder than

I Just Woke Up

. The name is an exaggeration of how much extra ballast one of the FA team felt like he was carrying, but don't we all feel this way sometimes?
content.location: This is the right of two routes that begin on a series of stepped ledges.
